title: What technology has been the least changed in the past 100 years? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m a retired electrical engineer. My grandfather was an engineer too. He attended Armor Institute, which is today the Illinois Institute of Technology. I inherited a couple of his old textbooks, and among them was one titled “Direct & Alternating Current Machines”, which is the study of AC & DC motors and generators. His text dates from 1917. I took Direct & Alternating Current Machines in 1970. Once I compared my grandfather’s textbook to the one I used when I took the same course topic. They are virtually identical texts … it was my impression that the field has not changed significantly in 100 years.

That is really an interesting and difficult sorta question; as most things have been improved, updated, changed, or enhanced. The AXE, chain saw, hand saw… non-motorized hand tools. Indoor plumbing (i.e., toilets), at least here in America. They are all basically the same,with just the two bowl shapes and amount of water being the primary differences. AC Power TO the house… how it’s created has changed in many areas, but the poles and lines, or underground options for the wire, are still the two most common and unchanged. Nearly any of the ANALOG radios (CB, Ham, UHF/Short Wave, AM Radio) Government actually solving problems… Kids today haven’t a clue about ‘winter freezing’ (of nearly everything, including outdoor faucets, wires, and motorized stuff); thanks to technological improvements.
